case.name: Canpoint International Pty Limited v Anar International Pvt Ltd [2008] FCA 4 (16 January 2008)

statutory demand
whether debtor has genuine offsetting claim against creditor
debtor claims unliquidated damages for economic loss
how can amount of claim be quantified for purposes of s.459h(2)
held: "genuine offsetting claim" for purposes of s.459h(1) and (2) corporations act means claim on a cause of action advanced in good faith, for an amount claimed in good faith
"good faith" means arguable on basis of facts asserted with sufficient particularity to satisfy the court that the claim is not fanciful
in an offsetting claim for economic loss the plaintiff must adduce evidence to show how the loss is said to arise and how it is calculated
if no such evidence adduced, court cannot find genuine offsetting claim.statutory demand
order subject to conditions
plaintiff's offsetting claim genuine but tenuous
court has discretion under s.459m whether to impose conditions upon an order setting aside statutory demand

held: as a condition of setting aside the statutory demand the court requires the plaintiff to commence and prosecute diligently proceedings to establish its claim and to pay a substantial sum into court to abide result of proceedings.acts cited: corporations act 2001

citances.sentence:
In Canpoint International Pty Ltd v Anar International Pvt Ltd [2008] FCA 4 , Stone J, in dealing with an offsetting claim in relation to loss of business, said (at [58] to [59]) as follows: [58] ... Whilst the Court does not require evidence of a standard expected on a final claim in applications of this kind, contradictions in evidence can be fatal if they make the claim as a whole implausible; see Edge Technology [2000] NSWSC 471 ; 34 ACSR 301. ... It is accepted that the amount claimed by the plaintiff may have "elements of uncertainty"; Elm Financial Services [2004] NSWSC 560 at [19] .
[59] In Edge Technology [2000] NSWSC 471 ; 34 ACSR 301 , a bare assertion of an amount for loss of profits without further evidence as to how that amount was calculated was held to be insufficient to ground a genuine offsetting claim in that amount; see Edge Technology at 316. ... The Court thus has sufficient evidence to say that the claim is genuine, whilst not seeking to assess the merits of the claim.
